channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: OPEC Move Shows the Limits of Biden’s Fist-Bump Diplomacy With the Saudis
item.description: OPEC’s decision to curb oil production was a signal that President Biden’s influence over his Gulf allies was far less than he had hoped.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Ben Hubbard
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia’s decision to support an oil output cut by OPEC and its allies on Wednesday marked another step of distancing from the United States.

item.title: OPEC and Russia Aim to Raise Oil Prices With Supply Cut
item.description: Led by Saudi Arabia, the oil cartel OPEC Plus pledged to reduce output by two million barrels a day.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refinery in Italy owned by Lukoil, the Russian oil company. The European Union is seeking to curb the revenue that Russia earns from oil sales.

item.title: E.U. Negotiators Strike Deal on Russian Oil Price Cap
item.description: The cap, championed by the United States, would deprive the Kremlin of tens of billions of dollars annually. Experts warn that implementation will be difficult.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A crude oil terminal near the port city of Nakhodka, Russia. With oil prices at a high, Russia is raking in billions of dollars in revenue, even as it sells smaller quantities.

item.title: In Retreat at the Front, Russia Strikes Deep Into Ukraine With Drones
item.description: In an attack in central Ukraine, Russian forces used what Ukrainians said were Iranian-made drones acquired by Moscow as its own arsenal dwindles.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Eric Nagourney
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Russia detonated “kamikaze” drones in Bila Tserkva, Ukraine, hundreds of miles from the fighting.

item.title: U.S. Believes Ukrainians Were Behind an Assassination in Russia
item.description: American officials said they were not aware of the plan ahead of time for the attack that killed Daria Dugina and that they had admonished Ukraine over it.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman, Adam Entous and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Daria Dugina’s memorial service in Moscow in August. U.S. intelligence agencies believe that parts of the Ukrainian government authorized the attack that killed her.

item.title: After Mar-a-Lago Search, Talk of ‘Civil War’ Is Flaring Online
item.description: Mentions in Twitter posts on the right have spiked during major political news events, and experts worry the overheated language will spread as the midterm elections draw near.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: Trump supporters outside Mar-a-Lago after the F.B.I.’s search in August. More Americans are anticipating, or even welcoming, the possibility of sustained political violence, researchers studying extremism say.

item.title: Some Florida Residents Demand More Federal Aid After Hurricane Ian
item.description: Hurricane Ian inflicted its worst damage across several deeply Republican counties, where many voters express hostility toward President Biden and the federal government in general.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Eliza Fawcett, Emily Cochrane and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage to residences on Pine Island was widespread.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Twitter Bid Puts Pressure on the Banks Backing Him
item.description: Looming in the background of Mr. Musk’s $44 billion offer to buy the company is whether financing challenges will provide him with an escape hatch from a deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch, Joe Rennison and Kate Conger
item.media:description: Elon Musk said on Monday night that he still wanted to buy Twitter. But financing the deal could be tricky.

item.title: For Pelosi and McCarthy, a Toxic Relationship Worsens as Elections Approach
item.description: The hostility between the speaker and the man in line to succeed her should Republicans win control of the House has only intensified as the decisive moment nears.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi could be succeeded by Representative Kevin McCarthy of California if Republicans take control of the House.

item.title: How a Christian Cellphone Company Became a Rising Force in Texas Politics
item.description: Patriot Mobile, based in a battleground suburb, is spending money to promote conservative views on race and gender in schools. It has its sights on bigger political targets.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Grapevine, Texas, and other communities in Tarrant County, candidates backed by the cellphone company Patriot Mobile have won elections to school boards.

item.title: Unveiled and Furious: How Iran’s Women-Led Protests Cut to the Heart of National Identity
item.description: The hijabs women are forced to wear have long been a sign of the government’s power. Now, the women-led protests have made them a symbol of a clashing vision of Iran’s future.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran in September, after the death of Mahsa Amini.

item.title: Eviction Looming For California Scofflaw And His Two Acres of Land
item.description: David Lee Hoffman has been fighting a local government in California for decades to keep his eccentric home and way of living intact.
item.dc:creator: Achy Obejas
item.media:credit: Matthew Millman for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Lee Hoffman has spent decades fighting Marin County, Calif., for the right to do as he wishes with his property. He could soon be removed.

item.title: What Does Sustainable Living Look Like? Maybe Like Uruguay
item.description: No greater challenge faces humanity than reducing emissions without backsliding into preindustrial poverty. One tiny country is leading the way.
item.dc:creator: Noah Gallagher Shannon
item.media:credit: Alessandro Cinque for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gauchos at the Pintado wind farm in Corral de Piedra, Uruguay.

item.title: How Bram Stoker’s Dracula Became ‘Dracula Daily,’ and an Internet Sensation
item.description: A recluse plagued by yearning and existential loneliness, the count found new life, and new readers, during the pandemic when the novel was serialized.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Connors
item.media:credit: Shawn Brackbill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Kirkland, creator of “Dracula Daily,” at his home in Lawrence, Kansas. He turned to the book during the pandemic, and found Dracula to be an unlikely patron saint for the uncertain times.

item.title: I’ve Studied 13 Days of the Cuban Missile Crisis. This Is What I See When I Look at Putin.
item.description: On the threat of nuclear war, he is escalating at every critical point.
item.dc:creator: Michael Dobbs
item.media:credit: Cecil Stoughton/White House Photographs, via John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum
item.media:description: President John Kennedy and national security officials during the Cuban missile crisis in October 1962.

item.title: Republicans on the March
item.description: So much Senate strangeness.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins

item.title: More on the Firing of That N.Y.U. Professor
item.description: It’s really just a routine bureaucratic affair.
item.dc:creator: Tressie McMillan Cottom
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: Education Divides Everything, Including Life and Death
item.description: Education divides everything, including life and death.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall

item.title: Where Are They Now? Trump Administration Edition.
item.description: Part of the resistance or part of the problem? It doesn’t matter: These lawyers are part of the gang.
item.dc:creator: Megan K. Stack
item.category: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Brian A Jackson, via Getty Images

item.title: The Singer I Loved Knew the Truth About No-Good Men and the No-Good World
item.description: Loretta Lynn was so committed to the rigors of loving herself that she suffered no one.
item.dc:creator: Hanif Abdurraqib

item.title: Why Parents Feel Like ‘Butter That Has Been Scraped Over Too Much Bread’
item.description: Things aren’t quite back to normal — whatever that was.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

item.title: Brazil’s Election on Sunday Showed That “Bolsonarismo” Is Here to Stay
item.description: Support for Brazil’s president is spread across the country.
item.dc:creator: Andre Pagliarini

item.title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen and Jessica Cheung
item.media:description: Leaders of oil-producing nations met in Vienna on Wednesday.

item.title: The Sudden Rise of Zach Bryan
item.description: The breakout country-folk singer and songwriter has found an audience for his old-fashioned artistry largely on a newer platform: streaming.
item.media:credit: Kristin Braga Wright for The New York Times

item.title: Is Fashion Week Embracing Responsibility?
item.description: Join Vanessa Friedman to explore the direct impact of Fashion Week and its cultural influence, especially as virtual trends emerge.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Scary Stories
item.description: It’s Spooky Season. What are your favorite scary books, movies, TV shows and podcasts?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Climate Change Made Summer Hotter and Drier Worldwide, Study Finds
item.description: Europe, China and North America were parched by extreme heat that would have been ‘virtually impossible’ without the effects of global warming, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: A field destroyed by a brush fire in the drought-ravaged village of Xinyao in Jiangxi Province, China, in August.

item.title: Former Uber Security Chief Joe Sullivan Found Guilty of Hiding Hack From Authorities
item.description: A jury found Joe Sullivan, who led security at the ride-hailing company, guilty on two different counts. The case could change how security professionals handle data breaches.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz

item.title: The Portland Thorns Become the Face of a Scandal in Women’s Soccer
item.description: The Portland Thorns were once the pride of U.S. women’s soccer. But after a report said the club shielded a disgraced coach and thwarted an abuse investigation, even the players are demanding a housecleaning.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper

item.title: In Israel, a Solemn Yom Kippur Also Creates a Giant Playground
item.description: Yom Kippur, the holiest day in Judaism, brings Israel to a standstill. For the nonobservant, that briefly turns highways into bike trails.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bikers in Tel Aviv on Ayalon Highway, typically one of the busiest roads in the Middle East, during Yom Kippur on Wednesday.

item.title: Why Does a Long Run Send Me Running to the Restroom?
item.description: Runner’s gut — which can include cramping, nausea and a sudden urge to “go” — can plague many runners during intense exercise. Here’s why, and how to avoid it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Are Scented Candles Toxic or Harmful to Your Health?
item.description: When candles burn, they release various vapors and particles into the air, but research suggests that using them is safe.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Does Magnesium Help You Sleep?
item.description: Studies have found a link between low levels of magnesium and sleep disorders. But changing your diet may be a better option than taking supplements.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin

item.title: How Can Oats, Which Don’t Contain Gluten, Be Labeled ‘Gluten Free’?
item.description: Oats, water, even sneakers may be advertised as “gluten-free.”
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan

item.title: Does It Matter if I Eat the Stickers on Fruits and Vegetables?
item.description: They won’t cause you any harm, but there are reasons to remove them before taking a bite.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Alvvays, a Dreamy Indie-Rock Band, Cranks Up the Volume
item.description: Molly Rankin’s group is known for emotional and melodic sophistication. Talking about its latest LP, “Blue Rev,” she reflected on how her family’s deep musical history led her there.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Gordon
item.media:credit: Wyatt Lowry for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Sheridan Riley, Abbey Blackwell, Molly Rankin, Alec O’Hanley and Kerri MacLellan of Alvvays. The band’s third album, “Blue Rev,” is out on Friday.

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
